comments: Let A be the tridiagonal unit-primitive matrix (see [Jeffery]) A = A_{9,1} = [0,1,0,0; 1,0,1,0; 0,1,0,1; 0,0,1,1]. Then a(n)=[A^n]_(2,3). - _L. Edson Jeffery_, Mar 19 2011From _Wolfdieter Lang_, Oct 02 2013: (Start)This sequence a(n) appears in the formula for the nonnegative powers of the algebraic number rho(9) := 2*cos(pi/9) of degree 3, the ratio of the smallest diagonal/side in the regular 9-gon, in terms of the power basis of the algebraic number field Q(rho(9)) (see A187360, n=9). rho(9)^n = A(n)*1 + B(n)*rho(9) + C(n)*rho(9)^2, with A(0) = 1, A(1) = 0, A(n) = B(n-2), n >= 2, B(0) = 0, B(n) = a(n-1), n >= 1, C(0) = 0, C(n) = B(n-1), n >= 1. (End)

example: From _Wolfdieter Lang_, Oct 02 2013: (Start)In the 9-gon (enneagon), powers of rho(9) = 2*cos(pi/9):rho(9)^5 = A(5)*1 + B(5)*rho(9) + C(5)*rho(9)^2, with A(5) = B(3) = a(2) = 3, B(5) = a(4) = 9 and C(5) = B(4) = a(3) = 1:  rho(9)^5 = 3 + 9*rho(9) + rho(9)^2. (End)
